Graphical abstract This paper provides a comprehensive review of the most recent advancements in single-atom catalysts for Li-S batteries, focusing on three key areas: the cathode, separator, and anode. Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have become a favorable contender for next-generation electrochemical energy storage systems due to their outstanding features such as high energy density, low cost, and environmental friendliness. However, the commercialization of LSBs is still characterized by critical issues such as low sulfur utilization, short cycle life, and poor rate performance, which need to be resolved. Single-atom catalysts, with their outstanding features such as ultra-high atom utilization rate close to 100% and adjustable coordination configuration, have received extensive attention in the field of lithium-sulfur battery research. In this paper, the preparation and characterization of single-atom catalysts for Li-S batteries are briefly introduced, and the latest research progress of single-atom catalysts for Li-S batteries is reviewed from three aspects: cathode, separator and anode. Finally, the key technical problems and future research directions of single-atom catalysts for lithium-sulfur batteries are also prospected, with a view to promoting the further development of commercialized LSBs. Keywords Single-atom catalysts Li-S batteries Polysulfide Redox process Shuttle effect Data availability statement The data that support the findings of this study are available from the corresponding author upon reasonable request. 1 Introduction With the increasing demand for fossil fuel energy, the development of advanced energy storage systems is crucial. Lithium-sulfur (Li-S) batteries have attracted attention for their high theoretical specific capacity (1675 mAh g−1) and large energy density (2600 Wh kg−1), as well as their large storage capacity of sulfur, low cost, and eco-friendliness, and are considered ideal next-generation energy storage systems. However, the practical performance of Li-S batteries is limited by a number of factors. First, the conductivity of sulfur and Li2S is very poor, leading to material loss and slow kinetics of the sulfur redox reaction. Second, the huge volume expansion of sulfur during cycling (≈80%) leads to severe structural degradation. Third, the “shuttle effect” of intense lithium polysulfides (LiPSs) and lithium dendrites seriously hinders the commercialization of Li-S batteries, which is also the focus and difficulty of Li-S battery system research [1–3]. In recent years, the use of a “catalytic” strategy to mitigate the “shuttle effect” has received widespread attention [4–6]. This strategy aims to accelerate the conversion between LiPSs and Li2S2/Li2S by improving the reaction kinetics of the conversion between sulfur species through catalysis. These catalytic polar materials also have adsorption capacity for LiPSs, so the “shuttle effect” can be mitigated by adsorption-catalytic synergy. The concept of single-atom catalysts (SACs) was proposed by Zhang et al. in 2011, which refers to this type of catalyst in which the catalytically active center is loaded on the surface of the carrier in the form of single metal atoms bonded to heteroatoms in the carrier [7]. Due to the high utilization rate of catalytic active sites (theoretically 100% utilization rate of metal atoms), homogeneous metal active centers, and unique electronic structure, SACs have shown extraordinary catalytic activity in many fields such as hydrogen evolution reaction (HER) [8–10], oxygen evolution reaction (OER) [11–13], and carbon dioxide reduction reaction (CO2RR) [14–16], etc. The many properties of SACs make them promising for applications in Li-S batteries. The advantages of single-atom catalysts applied in Li-S batteries include the following aspects: firstly, single-atom catalysts with extremely high catalytic activity can strongly anchor LiPSs, inhibit LiPSs diffusion, and can effectively accelerate the redox kinetics of LiPSs, thus alleviating the shuttle effect and improving the utilization of active substances. Second, when SACs are used to modify lithium metal anode, the highly dispersed single-atom active sites can uniformly regulate lithium deposition, and their lithophilic properties help to reduce the energy at the interface between lithium and the deposited substrate, thus lowering the nucleation overpotential and inhibiting the formation of lithium dendrites. The calculation results indicate that the metal-cation doping will lead to an upshift of the DOS at the Fermi level. It is because the new defect levels appear after the different metal cation doping as compared with that in the pristine catalyst, suggesting that a higher metallic behavior was obtained in all cation doping cases [17]. Finally, the commercial polypropylene (PP) separators currently used in Li-S batteries have large pores through which polysulfides can easily pass and cause diffusion. Separators modified with single atoms not only function as catalysts to inhibit the shuttle effect on the anode side, but also effectively prevent the generation of lithium dendrites by uniformly regulating the lithium-ion flux. In this paper, we briefly summarize the preparation and characterization methods of SACs and comprehensively review the recent research progress of SACs in the anode, diaphragm and anode of Li-S batteries (Table 1 ), and look forward to the future development of SACs in Li-S batteries [18–20]. 2 Synthesis and characterization of SACs In order to achieve greater breakthroughs in the field of catalysts, it is necessary to firstly solve the problem of how to realize high loading for single-atom catalysts, and secondly overcome the difficulty of carrier inhomogeneity, improve the binding effect between carriers and single atoms, and ensure that the single-atom catalysts have higher stability. Currently, the mainstream synthesis methods mainly include the top-down strategy (high-temperature pyrolysis, high-temperature atomic thermal migration, etc.) and the bottom-up strategy (atomic layer deposition (ALD), impregnation and adsorption, co-precipitation, ultra-low-temperature photochemistry, etc.). 2.1 The top-down strategy High-temperature pyrolysis is an important and efficient and favorable method for the preparation of single-atom catalysts because of its simplicity of operation and high yield. The preparation process usually uses solvothermal and hydrothermal methods to first dope the metal atoms into the precursor, and then the precursor is carbonized at high temperature in an inert gas, and the dispersion of the metal atoms is accurately controlled by utilizing the coordination of different heteroatoms to finally obtain the carbon-loaded metal single-atom catalysts. Metal-organic skeleton (MOF)-derived carbon with a specific pore structure, ultra-high specific surface area and good electrical conductivity has been widely used for single-atom catalyst preparation. Zn-based MOF is usually used as a precursor because Zn evaporates during pyrolysis at high temperatures to achieve selective removal. Metal ions such as (Fe, Co, Ni) with ionic radii and charge properties close to Zn2+ can then occupy the Zn sites to achieve uniform dispersion of single atoms. For example, Wang et al. obtained Co single atoms anchored on ultrathin nitrogen-doped porous graphene lattice materials (SA-Co/NGM) by pyrolysis of CoZn-ZIF-L nanosheets using metal chlorides as strippers and etchers [47]. Zhang et al. used glacial acetic acid as a catalyst to accelerate the polymerization of melamine and formaldehyde oligomer and as an etching agent for the decomposition of ZIF-67 etching agent, the melamine resin formed can act as a chelating agent to bind with Co2+ released from the decomposition of ZIF-67, thus preventing the Co atoms from agglomerating (Fig. 1 a) [48]. Finally, a unique Co-O2N2 coordination structure was formed after annealing at 800 °C. In addition to MOF, a large number of other 2D and 3D materials can also be used as sacrificial templates for the preparation of SACs. Wu et al. used discarded silk-glue fabrics as precursors for the preparation of 2D porous nitrogen-doped carbon-supported conductive substrates [49]. Due to its abundant amino groups and β-sheet structure capable of anchoring Fe/Co single atoms with N-coordination, it promotes the formation of two-dimensional structures and dispersion of metal single atoms (Fig. 1b). Ding et al. used a diatomite template and pyrolyzed it at 550 °C using NH4Cl as an ammonia source to form single atom Fe dispersed on a three-dimensional hierarchical C3N4 substrate (6.32 wt%) [30]. This bio-templating strategy prevents stacking of the carbon substrate, while the increased nitrogen content creates Fe-N2coordination, which greatly improves the Fe loading capacity and atom utilization. The ultra-high single-atom content enabled the S@3DFeSA-CN cathode to obtain excellent performance, with specific capacities of 1363.5 mAh g−1 and 783.0 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and 3.0 C. High-temperature atomic thermal migration is a method in which the metal–metal bond of a metal precursor is broken during high-temperature calcination, which in turn releases metal atoms. These metal atoms can be captured by carriers rich in nitrogen- and oxygen-containing species or anchor localization sites with edge defects, which in turn form stable single-atom catalysts. Lu et al. used high-temperature atom thermal migration to prepare Pt-SACs by physically mixing Pt/La-Al2O3 catalysts with CeO2 [50]. In flowing air at 800 °C, due to the strong interactions between the PtO2 and Ce powder, the Pt released from Al2O3 was trapped on CeO2, forming the thermally stable Pt1/CeO2. 2.2 The bottom-up strategy Although the top-down strategy has been widely used for the synthesis of SACs, it is difficult to precisely regulate the loading and precise dispersion of single atoms during high-temperature treatment in the top-down technique. Atomic layer deposition (ALD) is used as a thin film growth technique, which forms homogeneous films by layer-by-layer deposition. The method allows precise control of the amount of deposition by adjusting the number of ALD cycles, thereby controlling the amount of single atoms. The target SACs can also be controlled by selecting the appropriate metal precursors to be precisely fed into the reaction chamber [51]. Zhang et al. utilized an Ar plasma pair to etch Fe2O3 in order to form Fe2O3-Vo rich in oxygen vacancies, and subsequently deposited Pt atoms loaded with 2.59% (Pt-Fe2O3-Vo) on the surface of Fe2O3 nanosheets by ALD and hydrogenation [52]. DFT calculations demonstrated that the Pt-Fe atomic sites at the oxygen vacancies had higher binding energies, resulting in stronger electronic interactions between the Pt and Fe2O3 surfaces, which stabilized the Pt atoms (Fig. 1c). The impregnation method is one of the simplest and most economical methods for large-scale production of SACs. The principle of the traditional impregnation method is to impregnate the carrier in the precursor solution, so that the active substances are gradually adsorbed onto the carrier surface by electrostatic adsorption, and then activated at high temperature, and finally the carrier catalyst with better dispersion is prepared by the processes of drying and reduction. Zhang et al. immobilized SAC on graphene foam using simple liquid-phase impregnation, i.e., the precursor solution containing FeCl3, CoCl2 or NiCl2 was ultrasonicated together with GO dispersion, and then freeze-dried to obtain GO foam [53]. The prepared GO foams were then treated at 750 °C under Ar/NH3 conditions to reduce GO and metal ions to finally obtain Fe, Co, and Ni single-atom catalysts. Co-precipitation is also a commonly used method for the preparation of SACs. In the preparation process, the metal precursors and carriers are thoroughly mixed, followed by filtration, drying and calcination under specific conditions. The structure and properties of the synthesized catalysts depend greatly on the synthesis conditions, such as the titration rate of the precursor solution, the order, the reaction temperature, and the pH. Han et al. synthesized Pt single atoms loaded on hollow N-doped carbon nanotubes (HNCNT) by homogeneous precipitation method. ZnO nanorods were encapsulated using polydopamine (PDA) and then Pt(OH)4 was uniformly dispersed on the surface [54]. Subsequently, the Pt-Zn intermetallic compounds were obtained by H2 reduction at 800 °C. The Pt-Zn/HNCNT catalyst was finally formed by acid washing to remove ZnO. The ultra-low temperature photochemical reaction strategy involves the use of ultraviolet (UV) light to irradiate metal ion solutions at ultra-low temperatures to effectively control the nucleation between the reduced metal atoms to produce catalysts with dispersed metal atoms. Wei et al. used UV irradiation of ethanol-containing H2PtCl6 (Fig. 1d) by irradiating it at ultra-low temperature (−60 °C) [55]. In this −60 °C ultra-low temperature reaction, the ultra-low temperature suppressed nucleation, resulting in atomically dispersed Pt under ultra-low temperature conditions. 2.3 Characterization methods for SACs After the preparation of SACs, advanced characterization techniques are needed to determine the microenvironment, chemical state and coordination of the single atoms present, which is of great significance for the further design and synthesis of superior SACs. Currently, the main means to characterize SACs are high-angle annular dark field scanning transmission electron microscopy (HAADF-STEM), X-ray absorption fine structure analysis (XAFS), scanning probe microscopy, and infrared spectroscopy (FT-IR). 3 SACs for sulfur cathodes A suitable S composite electrode is the key to realizing high energy density and long-term cycling performance of Li-S batteries. However, the research of sulfur cathodes faces the following outstanding problems: (1) LiPSs are easily soluble in ether electrolyte, which causes shuttle effect and affects its cycling performance; (2) the kinetics of LiPSs conversion process is retarded, and the rate performance of the battery is poor. To address the above problems, researchers have successively proposed strategies of physical domain restriction, chemical adsorption, and catalytic conversion, among which the catalytic conversion strategy provides a practical solution to simultaneously inhibit the shuttle effect and enhance the rate performance. Due to the unique structure and high activity of single-atom catalytic materials, a great deal of research has been carried out in recent years on their application in Li-S battery cathodes. Using metal particles or single metal atoms as catalysts to promote the conversion kinetics of soluble LiPS to insoluble S or Li2S could also improve sulfur utilization and cycling life [56]. 3.1 SACs of different metal centers The key catalytic activity site in single-atom catalysts is the central metal atom, so the selection of suitable metal atoms is the key to achieving high catalytic activity. A large number of studies have focused on transition metal elements (including Fe, Co, Ni, Cu, Mn, etc.), which are the most popular and effective SAC center metal atoms in Li-S batteries due to their good electrical conductivity, tunable d-orbital structure, low cost and other inherent chemical properties. 3.1.1 Transition metal SACs Liu et al. prepared porous nitrogen-doped carbon single-atom iron catalysts by polymerizing and carbonizing diphenylamine in the presence of iron phthalocyanine and SiO2 hard templates (Fig. 2 a) [57]. Fe-PCN/S in the formation of nanoscale Li2S had a smaller LiPSs phase nucleation overpotential, which enhances the diffusion of lithium ions in Li2S. Therefore, the Fe-PNC/S composites have excellent rate performance and cycling stability in electrochemical tests. Wan et al. reported Co SACs (Co-N/C) loaded on nitrogen-doped graphene and used for Li-S battery cathode, the atomic dispersion state of Co on the graphene surface was observed by HAADF-STEM and analyzed and fitted by XANES and EXAFS, which gave the morphology and coordination configuration of the Co single atom, confirming that the Co single atom is embedded in the graphene lattice in a Co-N4 coordination configuration (Fig. 2b) [58]. Through experiment combined with theoretical calculations, it was found that the single atom Co could accelerate the nucleation and decomposition process of Li2S, and the Coulombic efficiency of the prepared sulfur anode S@Co-N/G was still as high as 99.6% after cycling 500 times at 1 C. Lim et al. [59] proposed that the introduction of SO2/S EEB sites adjacent to FeNC catalysts improves the LiPS adsorption strength and promotes the LiS electrochemistry kinetics, achieving a high-energy LiS pouch cell. This study is the first to demonstrate a strategy to manipulate the local environment of SACs by EEB sites, which will create a promising avenue for the design of advanced SAC-based cathodes for high-energy LiS pouch cells. Xie et al. systematically investigated the selective variability of the catalytic behavior of different metal atoms loaded on nitrogen-doped graphene (M-N-C) catalysts applied in Li-S batteries, as shown in Fig. 2c [60]. Combining the results of XAS characterization and DFT calculations, the authors found that the 3d orbitals of the central metal atoms would hybridize with the 2p orbitals of S, resulting in changes in the oxidation state and coordination configuration of the central metal atoms. After comparing the catalytic behaviors of Fe, Co, and Ni metal atoms, the authors found that the Fermi surface of Co is located in the 3d orbital, which possesses moderate interaction strength and is conducive to the anchoring of lithium polysulfide and the equilibrium of redox kinetics. According to XAS, it can be observed that the M-N/G are typical M-N4 planar structures and the bond length of the CoN bond is relatively short. During adsorption, the M-N-C structure will be changed, and the central atom will be detached from the planar center, while Ni has the weakest adsorption energy for lithium polysulfide among the three, and Co has the smallest change in d-Mout before and after adsorption, which indicates that its adsorption configuration is the most stable. The changes of the center metal atoms in different charging and discharging states can be analyzed by non-in situ XANES, and it can be seen that Fe and Co have higher initial average valence states, and during the discharging process, the change of valence state of Co is smoother than that of Fe; while during the charging process, the valence state of Co will rise back, which demonstrates the rapidity and reversibility of the redox kinetics of Co single atom. From a deeper understanding, the Co 3d orbital has a large number of unoccupied electronic states near the Fermi energy level, which is favorable for the subsequent electron transfer of anchored LiPSs and promotes the redox kinetics, while the 3d orbitals of Fe are more separated, which makes its electronic state easily affected by the S 2p orbitals, and manifests the high valence change in the process of electron transfer; and the absence of 3d orbitals in Ni leads to the weak heterogeneity of the Ni. Therefore, the Co-N4 adsorption capacity is the most moderate in terms of the active sites of planar structures. Theoretical calculations are an effective tool to study the interactions between LiPSs and adsorption catalytic materials from the perspective of electronic structure and molecular orbitals. First-principles calculations based on density-functional theory (DFT) have unique advantages in elucidating the reaction mechanism and providing design strategies to explain the reaction mechanism of catalysts for Li-S battery conversion at the atomic level. Compared with the experimental trial-and-error method, theoretical calculations have been used more systematically and extensively to predict and screen transition metals as SACs. In 2020, Cui et al. used 10 materials, including graphene, N-doped graphene, and N-doped graphene-loaded Fe, Mn, Ru, Zn, Co, Cu, V, and Ag SACs, as the objects of their study, and calculated the decomposition barriers, lithium-ion decomposition potentials, and lithium ionization rates with the help of DFT for Li2S on these 10 substrates [20]. With the help of DFT, the decomposition barrier of Li2S on these 10 substrates, lithium-ion diffusion, and its interaction strength with LiPSs were comprehensively analyzed and screened for SACs. As shown in Fig. 2d, the V single atom (SAV@NG) exhibited the lowest decomposition barrier (1.10 eV) and the highest binding energy for LiPSs (3.38 eV). They successfully synthesized nitrogen-doped graphene-loaded V-SACs (SAV@NG) under theoretical guidance and applied them to Li-S battery cathodes, and found that the discharge capacity, rate performance, and cycling performance of the batteries were significantly improved. Duan et al. carried out a comprehensive and systematic screening of 3d, 4d, and 5d transition metal atoms on N-doped graphene as single-atom catalysts for Li-S batteries [61]. The computational results show that the early transition metal catalysts have a strong adsorption capacity for sulfur, leading to the poisoning of their active centers by sulfur, which further affects the activity of the catalysts. The authors found M1/NG (M1 = Ru, Rh, Ir, Os) to be the most promising single-atom catalyst because of its small free energy change in the rate-determining step (ΔG Li2S* = 0.65, 0.55, 0.50, 0.63 eV) and low Li2S decomposition energy potential (E de-Li2S = 1.25, 1.17, 1.09, 1.12 eV), and faster diffusion of Li ions (E Li-difussion, all ≈0.28 eV) (Fig. 2e). Compared with other transition metal-based single-atom catalysts, these catalysts can effectively promote the formation and decomposition of Li2S solids during discharge and charging and significantly promote sulfur reduction reactions (SRR) and sulfur evolution reactions (SER). 3.1.2 High-loading SACs In the preparation and use process, in order to increase the active center of the catalyst, it is necessary to increase the single-atom loading. However, when the metal atom content is high, due to the ultra-high surface energy of the catalyst after its size is reduced to the single-atom scale, the single atoms are prone to agglomeration, resulting in the formation of nanoparticles, which reduces the catalytic activity and catalytic efficiency of the catalyst for SRR and SER. Therefore achieving high loading of high-center metal atoms has received extensive attention from researchers. The key to realizing the high-loading structure lies in the metal-substrate interaction strength higher than the metal–metal bond [62,63]. Li and colleagues used Co-SA as an excellent host material for good LSBs (Fig. 2g) [64]. XPS spectroscopy and adsorption experiments showed that Co-NC has a strong adsorption capacity for Li2S6. The formation of ST Co bonds and LiN bonds indicated that electrons were transferred from Li2S6 to the Co centers in CoSA–N–C. The adsorption energies of Li2S6 on CoSA–N–C and N–C were calculated to be −0.50 and −0.35 eV, respectively, which further confirmed that the Co and N atoms in CoSA–N–C acted as lithium and sulfur pro-sites to promote the adsorption of LiPSs and alleviate their dissolution and migration behaviors during battery operation. Ding et al. prepared dispersed single-atom Fe (6.32 wt%) on a 3D layered C3N4 substrate using a diatomaceous earth template and NH4Cl as an ammonia source. This biotemplating strategy prevented the stacking of the carbon substrate, while the increased nitrogen content formed Fe-N2 coordination, which greatly improved the Fe loading capacity and atom utilization. The ultra-high single-atom content enabled the S@3DFeSA-CN cathode to obtain excellent performance, with specific capacities of 1363.5 mAh g−1 and 783.0 mAh g−1 at 0.2 C and 3.0 C. The S@3DFeSA-CN cathode was characterized by a high specific capacity of 1363.5 mAh g−1 and 783.0 mAh g−1, respectively. 3.1.3 Dual-atom catalysts In addition to SACs, the introduction of additional elements to form dual-atom catalysts (DACs) with diatomic active sites has become a very effective strategy to further improve the catalytic performance in several processes. DACs provide additional degrees of freedom to optimize the catalyst’s electron level, additional adsorption capacity, and the possibility of more complex catalytic reactions due to their diatomic catalytic sites. Dual-active-site catalysts may be advantageous over SACs because their isolated single active sites interact with each other, and would improve the catalytic performance in the following aspects: (1) the coordination environment of active sites could be changed due to adjacent metal atoms, which can optimize the catalytic activity; (2) the neighboring dual active sites possess synergistic effects, which would lower the reaction energy barrier and facilitate the activation of chemical bonds in the PS conversion process. However, diatomic catalysts are more prone to agglomeration than monatomic catalysts, and the interaction mechanism between diatomic catalysts needs to be further understood [65]. Yang et al. prepared atomically dispersed Ni-N4 and Fe-N4 dual sites co-anchored on porous hollow carbon nanocages (Ni-Fe-NC) and used them as sulfur hosts for Li-S batteries [21]. The hollow conducting carbon matrix promotes electron transfer and also accommodates volume fluctuations during cycling. Notably, Fe exhibits a strong polysulfide affinity at the center of the high d-band at the Fe-N4 site, leading to the acceleration of the sulfur reduction reaction. Meanwhile, Li2S on the Ni-N4 site is metallic in nature and has a high S 2p electron density near the Femi energy level, thus realizing a low sulfur precipitation reaction potential. The dual catalytic effect on Ni-Fe-NC results in a high energy density, long lifetime, and low polarization rate of the sulfur cathode. Qiao et al. herein report a highly active Mn/CoNC catalyst with dual atom Mn/Co active sites coordinated on a N-doped carbon support [66]. The high-activity dual-site catalyst (Mn/CoNC) has been synthesized via CoMnO2|Ov initiated aniline polymerization; the oxygen vacancies in Co–MnO2|Ov can produce abundant defects in polyaniline and its pyrolysis-derived carbon, which are beneficial for loading of Mn and Co atoms. Based on experiments and DFT calculations, it is proved that the Mn/CoNC catalyst can effectively improve the utilization of sulfur, suppress the “shuttle effect”, and promote the conversion of polysulfides. To investigate the local structural evolution of the in situ occurring Pt-Cu diatomic active sites, Xie et al. performed in situ XAS tests (Fig. 3 f) [22]. Firstly, they clearly revealed the local structures of Cu NG, Pt NG, and Pt/Cu NG by combining EXAFS fitting, DFT calculations, and simulated XANES results. Then, the local structural evolution of Pt Cu bimetallic active sites that appeared in situ was investigated. They first performed FT-EXAFS operation on the edges of Pt L3 and Cu K. In the FT-EXAFS spectrum at the edge of Pt L3, in addition to the original Pt-C/N coordination at 1.60 Å, a new peak appeared at approximately 1.98 Å during the interaction between OCV and S8 molecules, which persisted throughout the entire electrochemical reaction process. In contrast, during the entire electrochemical cycle, the FT-EXAFS spectrum at the Cu K edge only showed a large peak originating from the Cu C/N scattering pathway. This difference strongly indicates that Pt sites, rather than Cu sites, preferentially interact with sulfur species. Subsequently, they further monitored the amplitude changes of the first coordination shell (below 2 Å) of Pt and Cu atoms to reveal the changes in the local coordination environment around the Pt Cu diatomic sites. During the discharge process, as S8 molecules are reduced to long-chain lithium polysulfides, the Pt-S coordination amplitude increases significantly. The “trade-off” between the peak amplitudes of Pt-C/N and Pt-S confirms the dynamic evolution of Pt atomic sites due to their strong interactions with sulfur species, which is highly consistent with the XANES results mentioned above. In sharp contrast, the peak intensity corresponding to the Cu-C/N scattering path remained almost unchanged, indicating the structural stability of copper atomic sites and their relatively weak interaction with sulfur species. In summary, the XAS results clearly indicate the synergistic effect of Pt Cu bimetallic active sites. The more dynamic coordination structure of Pt atoms promotes the adsorption of sulfur species on diatomic catalytic sites through strong interactions. At the same time, Cu atoms with stable coordination structures achieve effective charge distribution, allowing sulfur species to effectively desorb from diatomic catalytic sites. Therefore, the synergistic catalytic behavior of Pt and Cu atoms is the reason for the high catalytic efficiency of Pt Cu bimetallic sites, which greatly enhances the kinetics of sulfur redox reactions. 3.2 The coordination environment of the metal center The metal single atoms of SACs are not simply physically dispersed on the surface of the carrier but are chemically bonded and coordinated with the heteroatoms on the surface of the carrier. Currently, the metals in most SACs and the heteroatoms in the carriers are constructed through the classical four-coordination system. However, recent studies have shown that the symmetric electron distribution due to the symmetric structure in the classical four-coordination system is unfavorable for certain reactions [67,68]. Numerous electrocatalytic reactions have demonstrated that the electronic states of the metal atoms can be changed by adjusting the coordination number of the heteroatoms and the species of the coordinating heteroatoms, which in turn affects the electrocatalytic performance of SACs [69]. Shang et al. investigated the anchoring mechanism of Fe and N-Co-doped graphene (FeNx, x = 1, 2, 3, 4) and the adsorption of Li2Sn on FeNx by density functional theory [70]. The computational results show that FeNx has a strong affinity for Li2Sn due to the strong orbital hybridization and formation of chemical bonds between Fe and S atoms. This would favor the inhibition of Li2Sn (n = 4, 6, 8) dissolution and diffusion, as well as the homogeneous nucleation of Li2S and Li2S2. In addition, calculations show that the FeN and FeC bond lengths become shorter with the increase of the coordination number of N atoms, which is conducive to the enhancement of the bonding energies of FeN and FeC bonds, and thus improves the stability of Fe atoms in the doped system. Currently, the vast majority of SACs are coordinated to metal atoms via N atoms on the carrier. By changing the metal coordination atoms, e.g., replacing N with B, C, O, S, P, Cl, and F atoms, the charge distribution of the metal atoms can be adjusted, which can change the electrochemical properties of the active metal centers, and consequently affect the catalytic performance. As shown in Fig. 3a, Liu et al. loaded manganese single atom Mn/C(N, O) on O, N double-doped hollow carbon sphere frameworks [23]. It was demonstrated by XANES and EXAFS analyses that the O and N atoms could further stabilize the Mn atoms by acting as ligand atoms for the Mn atoms. The catalytic activity of Mn atoms was improved by effectively regulating the d-electron density of Mn atoms, and the Lewis acid-base properties of Mn atoms were enhanced to promote chemical interactions with LiPSs. Wu and Zhang et al. constructed a B and N co-coordinated iron SAC (SAFe @BCN) as shown in Fig. 3b [24]. In the asymmetric electronic structure N2-Fe-B2, the N atom acts as an electron acceptor and the B atom acts as an electron donor, and the N atom is more likely to get electrons from the B atom, so the Fe atom in the metal center retains 3d electrons. Therefore, the partial substitution of N atoms by B atoms is favorable for the off-domain distribution of electrons around the metal atoms, which enhances the affinity for LiPSs and accelerates the charge transfer during the transformation of LiPSs. The results of in situ Raman spectroscopy experiments show that LiPSs products can be detected in the cell using BCN material during the discharge process, while there is no obvious LiPSs signal in the cell using SAFe@BCN material, which confirms the strong affinity of this SAC for sulfur species and its high electrocatalytic activity for the sulfur reduction process. Sun et al. constructed porous nitrogen-doped carbon-loaded FeSA-Nx@PNC and porous nitrogen-phosphorus Co-doped carbon-loaded FeSA-PN@PNC, in which the coordination structure of FeSA-PN@PNC is FeN3P1 (Fig. 3c) [25]. To gain insight into the coordination geometry and the chemical state of prepared Fe atoms, X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) measurements were carried out. The maximum intensity at 2.2 Å−1 from Fe foil is associated with Fe–Fe bonding, the feature of which is not obvious for the FeSA-PN@PNC and FeSA-Nx@PNC. The adsorption edge position of FeSA-PN@PNC is located between Fe foil and Fe2O3, indicating the cationic coordination environment of the centered Fe sites. Furthermore, a downshifted edge position can be noticed for the curve of FeSA-PN@PNC in comparison with FeSA-Nx@PNC, implying a lower valence state of Fe in FeSA-PN@PNC. DFT calculations show that the d-band center (ε d) of FeN3P1 is higher than that of FeN, and higher ε d is expected to increase the antibonding orbital energy and reduce the corresponding occupancy, leading to stronger LiPS affinity and higher catalytic activity. The binding energies of FeSA-Nx@PNC surface for Li2S and Li2S6 were −2.19 eV and −1.16 eV, respectively, while the binding energies of FeSA-PN@PNC surface were drastically increased to −2.58 eV and −1.49 eV, which indicated that the binding energies of FeSA-PN@PNC for Li2Sx with stronger anchoring ability. In addition, the energy barriers for Li2S decomposition calculated based on FeSA-PN@PNC and FeSA-Nx@PNC were 1.52 eV and 1.64 eV, respectively, indicating that FeSA-PN@PNC reduced the energy barriers for the decomposition of Li2S, which in turn favored the kinetics of the sulfur oxidation reaction. The above results indicate that replacing one N atom in the FeN4 coordination system with one P atom is favorable for enhancing the adsorption of sulfur species and promoting the kinetics of the redox reaction between sulfur species. Du et al. anchored MgPc to a fluorinated carbon nanotube matrix (denoted as MgPc@FCNT) to modulate the electron distribution and energy level arrangement of the Mg sites by F coordination [71]. According to DFT calculations, the electron spin polarization in MgPc@FCNT not only increases the adsorption energy to LiPSs intermediates but also promotes the electron tunneling process in Li-S cells (Fig. 3d). Yan et al. synthesized a new type of SAC featuring a unique Mn-N3-Cl portion anchored on a B- and N-co-doped carbon nanotube (MnN3Cl@BNC) [72]. The Cl coordination effectively enhanced the electron cloud density of the Mn-N3-Cl portion, reduced the band gap, and increased the adsorption capacity and redox kinetics of LiPS (Fig. 3e). Li et al. synthesized the porous carbon matrix material using an in-situ polymerization-calcination method and doped with heteroatoms (N, S) in a SAMn catalyst [26]. The SAMn@NSC-Li2S6 complex exhibited a higher HOMO (Highest Occupied Molecular Orbital) energy level and a lower LUMO (Lowest Unoccupied Molecular Orbital) energy level compared to NC-Li2S6 and NSC-Li2S6 (Fig. 3f). As a result, the SAMn@NSC complex can accept and provide electrons more easily, which accelerates the kinetic process of redox reaction with LiPSs. Similarly, Dong et al. designed P, S co-coordinated asymmetric configurations of individual atoms in N-doped carbon regular dodecahedral nanocages (CoSA-N3PS) [27]. The local structure and coordination environment of CoSA-N3PS were tested, and the fitted curves showed a major peak at 1.32 Å and a second strong peak at 1.80 Å attributed to CoN, CoP, and CoS bond coordination, respectively. Meanwhile, as the pyrolysis temperature increases, the EXAFS spectra show higher intensities at 1.93 and 1.90 Å, which are due to CoS/P scattering, proving that P or S atoms have replaced nitrogen atoms. 3.3 Catalyst support 3.3.1 Carbon material SACs are loaded onto the carrier by forming chemical bonds with the carrier. Therefore, the properties of the catalyst carrier (e.g., the concentration and type of heteroatoms) have a large impact on the concentration and activity of the metal single-atom loading. On the other hand, the properties of the carrier (e.g., affinity to LiPSs) also affect the “shuttle effect”. The excellent electrical conductivity of carbon materials makes them ideal for SACs carriers. The rich variety of carbon materials provides a broad space for the selection of SACs carriers. Currently, researchers have reported various morphologies of carbon materials as carriers for SACs. Liu et al. prepared nitrogen-rich carbon nanocage materials loaded with FeSA using ZIF-8 as a precursor and used them as sulfur cathode carriers [73]. The rich porous structure and polar sites of the carbon nanocage effectively suppressed the shuttle effect of LiPSs, while the uniformly dispersed FeSA effectively promoted the conversion between sulfur species during the electrochemical reaction, shortened the lifetime of LiPSs, and further inhibited the migration of LiPSs. Chen et al. prepared highly ordered ZnSA-loaded nitrogen-doped carbon nanotube arrays as sulfur cathode carriers for Li-S batteries using the classical MOF material ZIF-7 as a precursor (Fig. 4 a) [28]. The regular 1D carbon nanotube structure promotes rapid mass transfer for the battery reaction at high sulfur loading, while the abundant single-atom active sites loaded on the carbon nanotubes effectively accelerate the conversion of LiPSs. Lim et al. prepared Ru-based single-atom electrocatalysts (Ru SACs) utilizing N-doped hierarchically ordered porous two-dimensional (2D) carbon nanosheets [29]. NCNS has an ultrathin 2D nanosheet morphology, which facilitates dense stacking of electrodes, and vertically aligned short porous channels, which allow electrolyte penetration and lithium-ion diffusion even in high-density electrodes (Fig. 4b). At the same time, Ru SACs are coordinated with two N atoms and Cl atoms by coordination (N2RuCl2). This synergistic effect of N2RuCl2 SACs and NCNS frameworks effectively solves the limitations of sulfur cathodes with low P E values and low E/S ratios. As a result, the Q v values of Li-S cells can be significantly improved even with high sulfur loading (5.0 mg cm−2), low E/S ratio (4.5 μL mg−1), and low PE value (50%). 2D carbon carriers with high specific surface area and layered structure can provide a large number of active sites when accommodating SACs [74,75]. This is the reason why 2D carbon-loaded SACs have been widely studied in the Li-S field. However, randomly formed 3D structures based on these 2D carbon-loaded SACs are usually weakly anchored to polysulfide molecules, resulting in poor sulfur utilization. In this regard, the assembly of these 2D-supported SACs through template strategies will lead to the generation of 3D-ordered architectures that will ultimately facilitate the adsorption and transformation of polysulfides to raise sulfur utilization efficiency. Sun et al. used diatomaceous earth as a template for the preparation of 3D structured nitrogen-carbon materials (3DFeSA-CN) loaded with FeSA, which were used as cathodes for Li-S batteries [30]. The multistage porous structure of 3DFeSA-CN material has a multistage porous structure that not only realizes high sulfur loading but also mitigates the volume change during electrochemical cycling. SEM characterization of the electrodes after cycling showed that the S@FeSA-CN cathode surface produces a large amount of sulfides and cracks, whereas the S@3DFeSA-CN surface is quite smooth without obvious cracks and agglomerations (see Fig. 4c). Li et al. used a bottom-up strategy to synthesize, by exploiting the supramolecular effect of metal–organic polymers, the porous nanocarbons supported on hierarchical layers of porous nanocarbons (SACs-Ni-NC) on vacancy-deficient Ni single-atom catalysts [31]. The N- and O-doped heteroatoms act as Lewis base sites with “lithophilicity” to inhibit the shuttle effect, while the vacancy-deficient single Ni sites (Ni-N3-V) act as Lewis acid sites with “sulfophilicity” to enhance the catalytic ability. As a result, S@SACs-Ni-NC has an initial specific capacity of 810 mAh g−1 at 5.0 C and maintains 78.5% of the specific capacity after 1000 cycles. Even when the sulfur loading was increased to 9.5 mg cm−2 (E/S = 3.9 µL mg−1), a capacity of 5.5 mAh cm−2 was still obtained at 2.0 C. Lin et al. reported a Fe-doped ZIF-8 nanocage and introduced it into inexpensive biomass bacterial cellulose (BC), which was converted into an aerogel structure by a subsequent pyrolysis process to obtain a nanocage with a carbon nanofiber network connections of Fe-SAC functionalized N-doped carbon nanocages (FeSA-NC@CBC) [32]. Benefiting from the highly conductive interconnected 3D framework of the CBC, fast electron and lithium transport and buffering of the volume expansion of the sulfur cathode can be achieved, while the atomically dispersed FeSA catalyst effectively and synergistically accelerates the kinetics of the polysulfide redox reaction. The prepared FeSA-NC@CBC composite cathode exhibits excellent rate performance with a reversible capacity of 840 mAh g−1 at 2 C and a long-term cycling stability of 800 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C. Unmodified carbon carriers cannot effectively trap LiPSs to mitigate the shuttle effect due to non-polarity [76]. Modification of nonpolar carbon carriers, such as heteroatom doping of graphene, can achieve significant enhancement of polysulfide capture [77–80]. Cui et al. achieved this by anchoring Ni single atoms and clusters to porous hydrogen-substituted graphene carriers (termed Ni@HGDY), which were bonded in the Li2S cathode [33]. Compared to conventional graphene-derived carriers, HGDY has a larger pore size (16.3 Å relative to the acetylene bond between), allowing for superior ionic transport while also providing good electronic conductivity of the π-conjugated network (Fig. 4d). By DFT calculations, single atom Ni binds most favorably to the two C atoms of the acetylene linkage, with an adsorption energy of −2.73 eV. Ni atoms bound to the center of the benzene ring adsorb poorly with a thermodynamic adsorption energy of −2.53 eV. The two- and three-atom Ni clusters are also most favorable for binding to the C atoms of the chain links, with total adsorption energies of −2.78 and −2.97 eV, respectively. These energetically preferred structures demonstrate the validity of the alkyne chain as a single-atom/few-atom Ni binding site. In the most favorable energetic configuration of the four-atom Ni cluster on HGDY, the cluster binds to the benzene ring and the acetylene chain. The involvement of the benzene ring in the tetra-atomic clusters suggests that the benzene ring may promote greater aggregation of Ni, and it is the acetylene linkage that allows HGDY to favorably stabilize both the small clusters and the single atom Ni, which translates into more active sites per unit mass of Ni catalyst. 3.3.2 Polar materials The nonpolar nature of carbon materials leads to weak interactions between the materials and polar LiPSs, limiting their ability to bind and confine LiPSs during cycling. Polar noncarbon substrate material-loaded SACs are widely used in catalytic applications, such as hydrogen generation and carbon monoxide oxidation, and exhibit excellent catalytic performance. Therefore, the development of highly polar noncarbon material substrate-loaded SACs is imminent, but the related research is still at an early stage in the field of Li-S batteries. MXene materials, i.e., 2D transition metal carbides/nitrides, have attracted much attention in the field of energy storage due to excellent electronic conductivity, large specific surface area, and structural tunability [81]. In 2015, Nazar et al. pioneered the application of MXene materials to Li-S battery cathodes [82]. Since then, a variety of MXenes materials began to be applied in the field of Li-S batteries [83–86]. Yang et al. introduced single-atom Zn into the MXene material Ti3AlC2 and prepared SAZn-MXene layered material (Fig. 5 a) [34]. The highly dispersed bright spots (Zn atoms) on the MXene nanosheets were revealed by HAADF-STEM images. Meanwhile, the electron cloud between Li2S4 and SA-Zn-MXene is much larger than that between Li2S4 and MXene, which indicates a strong interaction between Li2S4 and SA-Zn-MXene. Therefore, SA Zn-MXene can not only effectively adsorb LiPSs, but also promote the kinetics of the conversion reaction between sulfur species, thus realizing the excellent electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries. Metal sulfides have gained much attention in the field of electrocatalysis due to their excellent mechanical properties, thermal stability, and abundance of edge-active sites [87]. Zhao et al. systematically explored the potential of a series of metal atoms replacing Mo or S atoms in doped MoS2 monolayers as anchoring materials for Li-S batteries, including Mn, Fe, Co, Ni, Nb, Tc, Ru, Rh, and Pd [88]. DFT calculations show that the binding energy of MMo to Li2Sn is slightly increased (0.83–1.47 eV) by replacing Mo atoms with metal doping. In contrast, the substitution of sulfur atoms resulted in a significant increase in the binding energy of MS with Li2Sn (2.00 eV). It is noteworthy that CoS, NiS, and PdS have significant anchoring effects on Li2Sn due to the synergistic effect of the metal dopants and their neighboring S atoms, and can well preserve its structure from dissolving into the electrolyte. Metal oxides have been introduced as extremely promising sulfur immobilizers to improve cathodic sulfur electrochemical performance [89–91]. The polarity of many oxides (Co3O4, CeO2, TiO2, etc.) provides a strong trapping effect for LiPSs [92–94]. Among different oxide materials, TiO2 has been reported to be very effective as a semiconductor in the trapping of LiPSs in Li-S batteries. Xu et al. synthesized a conductive Ta/N co-doped TiO2 framework with a three-dimensionally ordered macroporous (3DOM) structure and embedded ZIF-67 derived co-anchored N-doped carbon (Co-NC) into this framework as an efficient sulfur host material [35]. The 3DOM Ta/N-TiO2 skeleton has good structural stability, which is favorable for electrolyte penetration and sulfur regulation. Meanwhile, the Ta/N co-doping not only improves the conductivity of TiO2 but also enhances the adsorption of LiPSs. In addition, the embedded Co-NC increased the active sites of the 3DOM skeleton for LiPSs conversion, which favored Li+ diffusion while providing additional small spores for sulfur confinement. Zhang et al. loaded single Fe atoms onto TiO2 nanospheres (Fe-SAC/TiO2 HNPs) [36]. Well-dispersed Fe single atoms occupy the most stable Ti vacancies, and replacing the Ti sites with heteroatoms with outer electrons lowers the energy barrier for sulfur conversion by tuning occupied and unoccupied orbitals near the TiO2 Fermi energy levels. The in-situ UV–visible test results show that the Fe-SAC/TiO2 HNPs can effectively capture LiPSs and accelerate the catalytic conversion reaction, inhibit the LiPS shuttle phenomenon on the surface of lithium metal anode, and enhance the electrochemical performance in terms of rate, and high loading capacity (Fig. 5b). Given that nonpolar carbon-loaded SACs face synthesis difficulties and process complexity, Islam et al. employed first principles to thoroughly investigate the adsorption mechanism of Li2Sn on WSe2-loaded V single atoms (V@WSe2), the kinetics of the sulfur reduction reaction, and the decomposition kinetics of Li2S (Fig. 5c) [95]. It is shown that WSe2 cannot anchor higher-order Li2Sn, while V@WSe2 provides strong adsorption energy for it, which is favorable for improving Li2S deposition kinetics in Li-S batteries. The results of this study are crucial for understanding the role of adsorbent materials in sulfur host design. 3.4 Multi-catalytic activity center Due to the limitation of the current SACs synthesis technology, the proportion of metal atoms on the carrier material is very low (usually less than 10% mass fraction), which undoubtedly affects the activity of the catalyst [96]. To increase the number of active centers, researchers have tried to improve the catalytic performance of SACs through the synergistic action of multiple catalytic active centers. Some integrated electrocatalysts containing single metal atoms and metal nanoparticles have been reported in recent years [37,38,97–104]. Zhao et al. constructed catalysts with double-end binding (DEB) sites by embedding polar ZnS nanoparticles and Co-N-C structured SACs into highly oriented macroporous conductive frameworks, which were used as anodic sulfur carriers [37]. Time-of-flight secondary ion mass spectrometry (ToF-SIMS) of S-secondary ions was performed on the S cathode of the cell and the Li metal after 100 cycles at 1 C (Fig. 6 a), and no S-migrating layer was observed in the ZnS/Co-N-C material, while only very weak S signals were detected on the surface of the Li-anode after the cycling, which confirmed the effectiveness of the DEB site in immobilizing the LiPSs. Wei et al. designed an SA-Fe (planar symmetric Fe-4N coordination) and Fe2N (triangular pyramidal Fe-3N coordination) co-doped N-doped graphene, which showed excellent catalytic selectivity for the lithiation and delithiation of LiPSs (Fig. 6b) [97]. Wei et al. constructed a three-phase interface consisting of an electrolyte (ether-based or solid polymer-based electrolyte), a conductive carrier (carbon nanofibers), and a catalyst (CoNPs and VSAs) (Fig. 6c) [38]. The conductive carbon nanofibers provided a smooth channel for electrolyte transport in the three-phase interface, while the synergistic effect of CoNPs and VSAs promoted the uptake and catalytic conversion of LiPSs. The CoNP-VSA@CF electrode exhibited excellent performance in all-solid-state Li-S batteries (ASSLSB) without adding LiNO3, with discharge capacities reaching 1289 mAh g−1 at 0.05 C and 0.5 C to 849 mAh g−1. However, the synthesis of such integrated electrocatalysts mainly relies on the high-temperature carbonization of specific precursors (e.g., MOF, MXene) or an excess of a single metal in the precursor, which makes it difficult to regulate the type of bimetallic combinations and nanoparticle size/distribution. Therefore, Yang et al. modified N-doped micro-mesoporous “sea urchin-like” hollow carbon nanospheres with abundant monatomic Fe-N4 sites and ultrafine VN nanoparticles (SA-Fe/VN@NMC), as shown in Fig. 6d [105]. The authors avoided the agglomeration of Fe single atoms by Fe-N-V pre-coordination, thus reducing the dissociation of Fe3+ from the liquid phase. Thanks to the strong chemisorption capacity of VN for LiPSs and the catalytic Li2S decomposition behavior, as well as the promotion of SA-Fe for the kinetics of the sulfur reduction reaction, SA-Fe/VN@NMC provides optimized adsorption catalysis for the multistep, multiphase redox reaction of sulfur species, and this integrated structure also promotes electron transport and lithium-ion diffusion. 4 SACs applied to separator modification It is worth noting that in the Li-S battery system, the separator is between the sulfur-positive electrode and the lithium metal negative electrode, and the lithium-ion transport channel of the separator is the only way for soluble polysulfide ions to enter the lithium-negative electrode region [106]. It is an effective research strategy to modify the separator reasonably and effectively to improve the comprehensive performance of Li-S battery. First, by means of physical confinement or chemical adsorption, on the premise of ensuring the lithium-ion channel and electronic insulation, the membrane is endowed with the ability to block the passage of polysulfides, and the dissolved polysulfide is limited in the positive area, so as to slow down the “shuttle effect.” Second, functional materials with excellent electrical conductivity were used to modify the membrane, which can be used as the “second collector” to activate polysulfide and improve the utilization rate of positive active material [107,108]. On this basis, the introduction of high catalytic activity nano materials can significantly enhance the reaction kinetics of polysulfide conversion, accelerate the liquid–solid (LiPSs-Li2S) conversion rate, improve the rate performance of the battery and the utilization rate of active substances, and inhibit the LiPSs shuttle effect [109,110]. On the other hand, the construction of a functional separator can promote the uniform deposition of lithium ions in the anode, stabilize the interface of the lithium metal anode, reduce the growth of lithium dendrite, or enhance the mechanical properties of the separator; the inhibition of polysulfide ions can effectively alleviate the uneven corrosion and deposition of Li and S on the anode surface [111]. Therefore, the construction of a functional separator can effectively protect the lithium metal anode. At present, the main separator materials used in Li-S batteries are polyethylene and polypropylene. Although these separators have lower production costs, better mechanical properties, and stable electrochemical properties, they also have some disadvantages such as poor wetting with electrolyte, low ionic conductivity, safety issues at high temperatures or pressures, and cannot effectively limit polysulfides due to pore diameters much larger than the diameter of the polysulfide molecules. Hence, the development of safer and higher-quality functional separators is the only way forward for batteries. The shape-controlled SACs owning high specific surface area, which promises effective contact with polysulfides and electrolytes, can maintain excellent chemical adsorption of soluble polysulfides. 4.1 SACs applied to separator modification Ren et al. developed a facile method to regulate the electronic structure of single-atomic catalyst by neighboring S doping of Fe-N4 active sites (Fe-NSxC) for efficient LiPSs trapping and conversion [42]. DFT calculations and experimental results prove that Fe-NSxC exhibits enhanced LiPSs adsorption and facilitated sulfur conversion compare to conventional Fe–N4 configuration, due to S doping-induced charge enrichment in Fe-NSC configuration (Fig. 7 a). Subsequently, they prepared Fe-NSC@GO single atomic catalyst by site precise S doping and used as functional separators for Li-S batteries. Consequently, Li-S cells using Fe-NSC@GO modified separators exhibited excellent cyclability with a low decay rate of 0.022% per cycle during 1000 cycles at 1 C and a high-capacity retention of 70.8% after 300 cycles at 3.0 C. Beyond that, even with a high sulfur loading of 5.1 mg cm−2, Li-S cells still showed a high sulfur utilization and stable cycle performance. Gu et al. rationally prepared d-block (Cu, Co, Ni, Mn, Zn) and p-block (In, Sn, Pb, Bi) metal single-atom catalysts supported on N-doped Ti3C2Tx for energy storage and conversion with high efficiency [43]. By applying asymmetrically coordinated M SA/N-Ti3C2Tx modified PP to Li-S batteries, the electrochemical performance of the separators was evaluated. Among the M SA/N-Ti3C2Tx s, we found that Cu SA/N-Ti3C2Tx displayed the best rate performance and cycling stability in the batteries. XAFS and DFT suggested that Cu-N1C2 active sites increased the binding energy between Cu SA/N-Ti3C2Tx and LiPSs, effectively suppressing the shuttle effect of LiPSs (Fig. 7c). Furthermore, the introduction of Cu single atoms greatly improved the conversion kinetics of LiPSs. This work successfully combines metal single atoms with highly conductive Ti3C2Tx, providing valuable insights for the development of single atom-decorated ultrathin 2D materials in high-performance Li-S batteries. Wang et al. constructed and utilized a CoSA catalyst as a coating layer on a separator to catalyze polysulfide conversion in Li-S batteries [18]. The atomic Co distribution within the carbon skeleton can expose abundant active sites and remarkable catalytic activity, thus facilitating rapid polysulfide conversions. Consequently, Li-S battery performance is significantly enhanced with the Co-NPC coating layer under both low and high areal sulfur loadings, in terms of specific capacity, rate performance, and long-life cyclic stability. Further in situ characterization, theoretical simulations, and TOF-SIMS verify the high catalytic capability of CoSA towards reversible polysulfide conversions (Fig. 7d). Zhang et al. constructed three SACs, namely, Mo-N3, Mo-N2C1, and Mo-N1C2 [40]. The d-band centers of the Mo-N3 structure are the closest to the Fermi energy scale and the d-band center in the Mo-N1C2 structure is farthest from the Fermi energy level. The authors concluded that the strong adsorption of LiPSs by the Mo-N3 structure may lead to the difficulty of desorption of adsorbed LiPSs and rapid passivation of the catalyst, thus reducing the utilization of active sulfur, while the weakest adsorption of LiPSs by the Mo-N1C2 structure may lead to the inability of the catalyst to efficiently capture LiPSs; and that the Mo-N2C1 structure optimizes the adsorption and catalytic conversion between Mo and LiPSs. The results of the adsorption and cycling performance experiments showed that Mo-N2C1 realized the effective adsorption and de-adsorption as well as conversion of LiPSs during the electrochemical cycling process (Fig. 7e). 4.2 DACs applied to separator modification By constructing binary metal SACs in order to form a highly conductive network that promotes the conversion aspect of LiPSs, the synergistic catalytic activity of different metal atoms for LiPSs is also exploited. Ling et al. designed an electrocatalyst consisting of N-bridged Fe-V diatomic active sites (Fe/V-N7), which are dispersed on ingenious “3D in 2D” carbon nanosheets (DAC for short), a morphology that promotes uniform distribution of sulfur and exposes a large number of active sites [39]. At the same time, V can induce the laminar structure and modulate the coordination configuration of the active centers, which realizes the redistribution of electrons in the 3d orbitals of the Fe centers. The high degree of coupling between the Fe/V 3d electrons and the S 2p electrons reveals the strong affinity and enhanced reactivity of the DAC-Li2Sn (1 ≤ n ≤ 8) system. As a result, the assembled Li-S cell has excellent cycling stability (637.3 mAh g−1 after 1000 cycles at 1 C) and high doubling capacity (711 mAh g−1 at 4 C). Ma et al. constructed a highly efficient electrocatalyst composed of N-coordinated binary metal SAs as a separator coating for boosting the electrochemical performance of Li-S batteries [112]. Benefitting from the highly conductive networks and synergistic catalytic activity of binary metal SAs in promoting the conversion of polysulfides, Li-S batteries with the Fe/Co-N-HPC-modified separator delivered greatly enhanced electrochemical performance under both low and high areal sulfur loadings, in terms of specific capacity, rate capability and long-life cyclic performance. Moreover, in situ characterization and theoretical simulations confirmed the bilaterally catalytic effect of binary metal SAs toward polysulfide conversion. 4.3 High-loading SACs-modified separators Further enhancing the single-atom loading of SACs to enhance their adsorption capacity and catalytic activity for polysulfides, and thus effectively suppressing polysulfide shuttling and lithium dendritic problems has been of wide interest to researchers. Guo et al. obtained a bifunctional separator (B/2DMOF-Co) prepared by layer-by-layer assembly of bacterial cellulose and two-dimensional ultrathin MOF-Co (Fig. 8 a) [113]. In the resulting self-supported functionalized separator, the regularly arranged Co atoms were exposed on the surface of the MOF nanosheets after coordination with O atoms (Co-O4) to exhibit a single-atom array state, and the mass fraction of cobalt atoms was as high as 24.8 wt%. Experimental and theoretical computational analyses revealed that, on the anode side, 2DMOF-Co nanosheets with periodically arranged Co-O4 structure and enhanced mechanical modulus on the surface can homogenize the lithium-ion flux through strong lithium ion adsorption, which contributes to the uniform nucleation of Li and inhibits the growth of Li dendrimers; on the anode side, the 2DMOF-Co nanosheets can be efficiently anchored through Lewis acid-base interactions LiPSs, limiting LiPSs diffusion and improving sulfur utilization. The cells assembled based on B/2DMOF-Co separator showed good discharge capacity and cycle stability. At a high sulfur loading of up to 7.8 mg cm−2, the capacity of the assembled battery was still as high as 5.0 mAh cm−2 after 200 cycles. Sun et al. synthesized Ni and melamine co-doped ZIF-8 precursor (Ni-ZIF-8-MA) by introducing melamine and Ni simultaneously during the synthesis of ZIF-8, which significantly reduced the particle size of ZIF-8 and further anchored Ni through Ni-N6 coordination (Fig. 8b) [114]. Therefore, through high-temperature pyrolysis within an N-doped nanocarbon matrix (Ni@NNC), a unique Ni single-atom catalyst, with a high loading of 3.3 wt%, has been created. The catalyst exhibited excellent catalytic effects on the electrochemical transformations of LiPSs as a separator modifier, resulting in a high specific capacity of 1232.4 mAh g−1 at 0.3 C and an excellent specific capacity of 814.9 mAh g−1 at 3 C for the corresponding Li-S batteries. 4.4 Acquisition of new single-atom catalysts Due to the high surface free energy of monometallic centers, single atoms are chemically unstable and tend to aggregate into metal nanoparticles, and the synthesis process of SACs based on spatial confinement strategies usually involves complex defect engineering of the substrate material and high-temperature pyrolysis. Therefore, the development of effective methods to obtain stable SACs with high catalytic performance has attracted the attention of many researchers. ALD, as a thin film growth technique, has the advantages of excellent uniformity, atomic-level thickness accuracy and high reproducibility. Thanks to the alternating self-limiting nature of the deposition process, ALD technology allows for the controlled and precise synthesis of single atoms. Lin et al. modified single-atom dispersed cobalt on a 3 µm-thick carbon nanotube film by ALD, and prepared Co-loaded carbon nanotube thin-film catalysts (CNT@SACo), which are used as multifunctional interlayers for lithium-sulfur batteries (Fig. 8c) [115]. Cells assembled from CNT@SACo separators exhibit high capacity, long-term cycling stability and excellent rate performance. Most of the reported SACs for Li-S batteries are based on d-band transition metals whose d orbitals form the active valence band, which tends to undergo catalyst passivation. SACs based on valence orbitals within the 4f of rare earth metals are challenging because they are extremely difficult to activate. Zhou et al. designed and synthesized Sm SACs with electron-rich 4f internal orbitals to facilitate the catalytic conversion of polysulfides and uniform deposition of Li (Fig. 8d) [41]. Using the improved separator with Sm-N3C3, the half-cell could provide a high capacity of more than 600 mAh g−1 with a retention rate of 84.3% after 2000 cycles. The fabricated Sm-N3C3-Li|Sm-N3C3@PP|S/CNT full cell provides ultra-stable cycling performance with 80.6% retention at 0.2 C after 100 cycles, making it one of the best full Li-S cells. This work provides a new perspective for the development of rare earth metal single-atom catalysis for next-generation energy storage in electrochemical reactions in Li-S batteries and other electrochemical systems. 5 SACs for lithium anodes There is a common problem in Li-S batteries with Li-Metal as the negative electrode, i.e., the sharp Li-dendrites resulting from successive streaking/deposition can puncture the separator and lead to an internal short circuit. The rational design of lithium substrates has been developed as a promising approach to accommodate volume expansion during charging and discharging and to inhibit lithium metal corrosion. For Li-S batteries, on the one hand, SACs accelerate the conversion reaction by adsorbing polysulfides, forming chemical bonds such as metal-S bonds and NLi bonds, and weakening LiS bonds to reduce the energy barrier of the polysulfide conversion reaction. At the same time, it reduces the uneven distribution of polysulfides on the surface of the negative electrode, creating a stable environment for the uniform deposition of lithium metal. On the other hand, the single-atom catalyst also affects the charge distribution on the electrode surface, which induces a more uniform distribution of the electric field and guides the lithium ions to be uniformly deposited on the anode surface under the action of the electric field. Exploration of single-atom metals on nitrogen-doped graphene substrates (labeled SAM-NG, where M = Ni, Pt, Cu) as stable hosts for Li metal deposition was reported by Gong et al. [116]. Isolated and dense metallic atoms coordinated with nitrogen atoms on graphene can increase the lithium adsorption energy in localized regions around the metal atom sites with a moderate adsorption energy gradient, thus preventing structural damage and guiding the uniform deposition of metallic lithium on the carbon surface during long-term cycling. As shown in Fig. 9 a, in contrast to isolated Li nucleation and subsequent Li dendrite growth on pristine graphene (PG), uniform nucleation and dendrite-free deposition can be achieved on SAM-NG. Similarly, Yan et al. quantitatively demonstrated by molecular dynamics simulations that uniform and stable lithium metal plating/stripping behavior was achieved induced by uniformly distributed FeSA-N in a carbon matrix, which greatly suppressed the growth of lithium dendrites [117]. Xu et al. demonstrated that single-atom Zn sites can improve the nucleation process and further drive the high-dimensional Li deposition kinetics (Fig. 9b) [44]. DFT calculations showed that ZnN4/PCSAC with Zn-N4 centers has a higher negative adsorption energy (−3.36 eV) compared to graphene (−2.37 eV) and N-doped graphene (−2.72 eV), which is favorable for Li atom binding. In addition, the polarization potential for Li nucleation on ZnN4/PC-SAC is smaller compared to that of Ketjenblack (KB). The Li nucleation sites increased with the increase in the density of active sites of Zn atoms (Fig. 9b). The Li-S battery assembled with Li-ZnSAs anode has a first-cycle discharge capacity of 1220 mAh g−1 at a current density of 0.2 A g−1, and the capacity retention can still reach 600 mAh g−1 after 200 cycles. Wu et al. synthesized Zn single-atom modified hollow porous carbon shell (Zn1-HNC) nanoreactors by pyrolysis of hollow-structured ZIF-8 precursors with single-atom loadings up to 15.7% [45]. Unlike the uneven deposition and poor Li dendrites on the surface of the bare Cu electrode, the growth of Li dendrites was effectively suppressed on the homogeneous Zn single atom lithophilic sites of Zn1-HNC, and ultrafine and smooth Li nucleation was realized (Fig. 9c). The Li-S full cell assembled with Zn1-HNC-S cathode and Zn1-HNC-Li anode showed only 0.015% capacity decay rate in 700 cycles and still had a discharge capacity of 989 mAh g−1 at 10 C. Sun et al. added (Co, Zn)-coordinated zeolite imidazolium skeleton (Co-ZIF-8) to the solution of nanofibers prepared by the electrostatic spinning method, and then thermally decomposed to obtain a fibrous carbon skeleton with single-atom dispersed Co-Nx (Co-PCNF) [46]. As shown in Fig. 9d, this network structure endows the fibrous skeleton with excellent mechanical properties of bending and folding. Co-PCNF can effectively promote the electrochemical bidirectional conversion kinetics of sulfur when applied to the sulfur cathode, thus inhibiting the shuttle effect of LiPSs; when applied to lithium anode, it can enhance the lipophilicity of the fibrous carbon skeleton and promote the homogeneous lithium nucleation and growth of the negative electrode, thus inhibiting the formation of lithium dendrites. S/Co-PCNF||Co-PCNF@Li full cell has a cycle life of 600 cycles at a sulfur loading of 3.5 mg cm−2 at 0.2 C, with a capacity decay rate of only 0.082% per cycle. Even at a high sulfur loading of 6.9 mg cm−2, a face capacity of 7.15 mAh cm−2 is achieved at 0.1 C. The combination of carbon nanofibers with polyhedral ZIF-8 was achieved by the electrostatic spinning method by Wang et al. [19]. The precursor was then carbonized to prepare a Zn single-atom dispersed hierarchical porous carbon nanofiber network (ZnSA@HPCNF) as a lithium-metal host material with ultra-stable plating and exfoliation properties (Fig. 9e). Advantages of ZnSA@HPCNF include (1) its flexible structure, which lays the foundation for the design and preparation of a flexible Li-S all-cell battery; (2) a high specific surface area of the layered porous structure, which facilitates electron transfer; and (3) its Zn atoms provide more deposition sites and homogeneous lithium surface nucleation. Li/ZnSA@HPCNF symmetric cells exhibit stable nucleation overpotentials during electroplating/stripping, which lasts for up to 900 h at 5 mA cm−2, showing reliable lithium electroplating, stripping, and dendrite inhibition capabilities. The S/CNT||Li/ZnSA@HPCNF full cell shows the high reversible specific capacity of 751 mAh g−1 after 500 cycles at 1 C. These findings confirm that the application of SACs to inhibit lithium dendrite growth in Li-S batteries and indeed all lithium-metal batteries show great promise and that uniform lithium deposition can be readily achieved on SACs-modified bodies. However, we can see that there are few publications on the modification of Li metal anodes to inhibit lithium dendrite growth compared to the extensive work on modifying S cathodes and separators. Therefore, further research on SAC for lithium anode protection is worthwhile. 6 Conclusions and outlook This paper presents a comprehensive review of the mainstream preparation and characterization methods of SACs materials as well as research advances in Li-S battery cathode, separator and anode applications in recent years. SACs have a unique electronic structure and maximized atom utilization, which can enhance the adsorption of LiPSs, promote the conversion kinetics of LiPSs, and improve the rate performance of the batteries. Moreover, SACs can inhibit the growth of lithium dendrites as lithophilic sites. However, in general, the current research work on the application of SACs in Li-S batteries is still limited, and there is still a vast research space and potential in this research direction. (1) Firstly, the study of metal centers of SACs in Li-S batteries mainly focuses on the transition metal elements in the fourth cycle, and other metal elements and non-metal elements are less concerned or have not been studied. Secondly, the current loading of metal atoms for SACs is generally low, so precise adjustment of the coordination environment of metal centers to further improve the role of active centers, as well as the addition of vacancies as the anchoring positions of SACs, are required to obtain highly loaded SACs. Finally, the current single-atom catalyst preparation is concentrated in the laboratory, with low catalyst yields, and the future should be devoted to the research of efficient and inexpensive methods of large-scale preparation of research on the method of SACs. (2) SACs applied to Li-S batteries, the carrier, in addition to affecting the loading and structure of SACs, should also have a high conductivity to rapidly transfer electrons, alleviate volume expansion, porous interconnection structure to increase sulfur loading, and physically limit the role of LiPSs shuttling, and so on, and therefore further optimization of the structure of the carrier material is also needed. Attention should also be paid to the application of SACs under practical conditions such as poor electrolyte and high sulfur loading to promote the practical application of single-atom materials in Li-S batteries. (3) Although the catalytic mechanism of SACs in Li-S batteries is currently understood, the more in-depth reaction mechanism is still unclear, and further theoretical studies and in situ characterization methods are needed to gain a deeper understanding of the relevant mechanisms and provide theoretical guidance for the design of SACs in Li-S batteries. (4) The use of non-flammable solid electrolytes instead of organic electrolytes for the preparation of ASSLSBs is an effective strategy to alleviate the safety problems caused by flammable organic solvents. However, as the sulfur content increases, the solid electrolyte and conductive carbon content in the cathode composite will inevitably decrease, which will deteriorate the transport of lithium ions and electrons in the cathode composite. Therefore, designing a new type of superior SACs for ASSLSB application is one of the effective research directions in the future. Some anticipated solutions can be proposed to the above problems related to SACs in lithium-sulfur batteries. (1) Develop the potential of fifth and sixth-cycle transition metals and main group metals in SACs by designing new experiments. It is also possible to further increase the variety of central metal atoms to obtain comprehensive catalytic effects. (2) Meanwhile, for the currently existing SACs, we can use machine learning algorithms to analyze a large amount of existing SACs synthesis data, combine with experimental feedback to establish a model between metal atom loading and synthesis conditions (e.g., temperature, precursor concentration, and reaction time, etc.), and predict the combination of synthesis parameters for high loading through AI, and conduct experimental exploration accordingly to realize the loading enhancement. (3) Combine various advanced in-situ characterization techniques (e.g., in-situ XRD, in-situ TEM, etc.) to monitor the structural evolution and chemical environment changes of SACs during the charging and discharging process of lithium-sulfur batteries in real time, so as to correlate the performance with the dynamic information of the structure. (4) Use quantum chemical calculations, molecular dynamics simulations and other theoretical methods to investigate the reaction pathways, intermediates formation and conversion and other microscopic processes, to establish accurate catalytic mechanism models, to provide an accurate theoretical basis for experimental design, such as designing the structure of SACs with specific catalytic sites based on the first nature principle calculations. Shengmin Chen is currently pursuing his master’s degree at the School of Materials Science and Engineering College, Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen), China. His research interest focuses on the use of ionic liquid-assisted synthesis of single-atom catalysts with applications in cathode and separator modification for lithium-sulfur batteries. Guanglei Li is currently pursuing his master’s degree at the School of Materials Science and Engineering College, Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen), China. His research interest focuses on the use of ionic liquid-assisted synthesis of single-atom catalysts with applications in cathode and separator modification for lithium-sulfur batteries. Zhenye Zhu is currently a professor and doctoral supervisor at the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen), China. He received his PhD degree from Harbin Institute of Technology in 2007. His research focuses on energy materials and devices. Rongshu Zhu is currently a professor and doctoral supervisor at the School of Civil and Environmental Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen), China. She received her PhD degree from Wuhan Institute of Physics and Mathematics, Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2013. Her research focuses on Environmental and Energy Catalysis. Jiaheng Zhang is currently a professor and doctoral supervisor at the School of Materials Science and Engineering, Harbin Institute of Technology (Shenzhen), China. He received his PhD degree from China Agricultural University in 2013. His research focuses on ion liquid.

coredata.dc:description: Lithium-sulfur batteries (LSBs) have become a favorable contender for next-generation electrochemical energy storage systems due to their outstanding features such as high energy density, low cost, and environmental friendliness. However, the commercialization of LSBs is still characterized by critical issues such as low sulfur utilization, short cycle life, and poor rate performance, which need to be resolved. Single-atom catalysts, with their outstanding features such as ultra-high atom utilization rate close to 100% and adjustable coordination configuration, have received extensive attention in the field of lithium-sulfur battery research. In this paper, the preparation and characterization of single-atom catalysts for Li-S batteries are briefly introduced, and the latest research progress of single-atom catalysts for Li-S batteries is reviewed from three aspects: cathode, separator and anode. Finally, the key technical problems and future research directions of single-atom catalysts for lithium-sulfur batteries are also prospected, with a view to promoting the further development of commercialized LSBs.
